Award.AwardTitle: Examining Motivation in Engineering Writing Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Writing is an important skill for both academic and professional engineering success. While low student motivation to master engineering writing is an impediment to the success of engineering writing classes, it has not been addressed much in engineering educational research. This project will conduct a mixed methods research study on student motivation and attitudes on engineering writing and then use the results of the study to a create tool for instructors to apply these findings. Research-based insight into student motivation, paired with an opportunity to learn about motivational psychology, will provide instructors with both the foundation and tools to understand and positively influence student motivation and develop student-centered learning in engineering writing classes.

The first objective of this project is to research the motivation of students of engineering writing classes to provide an evidence-based portrait of engineering writing students' motivation and influential experiences. In the second project objective, personas of engineering writing student motivation will be created as faculty development tools to foster the translation of this research into the enrichment of the teaching practices of engineering educators. Personas are brief narratives that distill research into a set of brief fictional personalities and narratives, which reduce the abstraction of user data by illustrating it with a human character, and have been used in the software development and product design. This research will build on existing motivational theories, including Expectancy Value Theory, and research to gain knowledge on student motivation in engineering writing as well as related work on the development and use of personas to bridge the research-to-practice gap in engineering teaching and learning. In this mixed methods research study, the Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire (MSLQ) will be used to survey a broad and diverse cross-section of engineering writing students. In addition, the project team will conduct semi-structured interviews to further examine the attitudes, concepts, and experiences that shape student writing motivation, with the aim of identifying pedagogies that will provide positive influence on students' motivation and learning. The development of personas based on the survey and interview data and dissemination through faculty development workshops and support will help translate this research into practice and therefore impact students' motivation favorably. The evaluation plan, which includes formative and summative, will help ensure that this work has broader impact beyond the institution and can be adapted at other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering student motivation to master and perform writing is often considered problematically low by the engineering community. Educators associate low student motivation to disappointing student communication performance and learning, poor class behavior, and lack of student engagement in comparison to more technical classes. Though the effects of low motivation are easy to see, the causes are not?are students reacting to their own poor prior experiences writing, or a belief that engineering should not require writing, or a general dislike of writing as an activity, or other factors entirely? In order for instructors to help students to have more constructive motivations in the future, they must better understand students? motivations in the present.

 

This project seeks to provide an evidence-based understanding of the learning motivations of today?s engineering students in their writing courses, with an eye toward providing insights that educators may immediately apply to their educational designs. We surveyed 715 students enrolled in writing classes at two large universities on their learning motivations in their writing class and another engineering class with no graded writing, using Expectancy-Value Motivation and Writing Apprehension frameworks. From these students, we recruited 22 students for semi-structured interview to discuss the factors and experiences that shaped their ideas about writing and their experiences in writing courses.

 

The conclusions of our analysis challenged many well-known stereotypes about engineering students.  First, today?s engineering students are well aware that the profession involves a substantial amount of writing. A large majority also believed that the content of their writing classes is important to their future career in school and beyond.

 

Second, even though the students themselves often professed the belief that engineering students are bad writers, our data suggests otherwise; a plurality of the students in this study were capable and confident writers who enjoyed writing. All classes that we surveyed contained a full spectrum of adept writers and reluctant writers. 

 

Third, demotivation is indeed present among writing students, but often due to underdiscussed factors. Writing apprehension, which is a poor emotional response to the act of writing or being evaluated, was a certainly a prominent demotivating factor, and many courses have been designed to be easy as a means to relieve this apprehension. However, designing courses with remedial intent contributes to a different strongly demotivating factor: when writing coursework is perfunctory, many students are not able to experience the rewarding effects of meeting challenges, intrinsic interest in complex material, and pride in their achievements. Our research suggests that making courses increasingly easy is most likely contributing to demotivation rather than ameliorating it.

 

Our work also focused on practical insights that instructors may apply immediately. Chief among them: manipulating grades (higher to increase self-efficacy, or lower to imply high standards) is not a promising universal way to increase motivation. In fact, if a student believes that course grades are arbitrary, grades become demotivating. Adopting improved rubrics; coaching students individually; helping to uncover writing mechanics, logic and design thinking; and showing authentic example texts, were all techniques that helped students in this study to find writing more achievable and thus more motivating.

 

Though students did not find grades to be motivating, they responded very positively  to writing about interesting topics. Strong writers enjoyed the opportunity to stretch their skills, and reluctant writers appreciated the ability to use an interesting topic as a means to self-motivate. However, a divide existed within the students? preferences for interesting topics: students who were further along in their academic career, who had more significant authentic experience through internships or extracurriculars, and students whose leisure reading habits had significantly informed their career decisions, all preferred the freedom to choose their own topic. Students who were newer to the discipline dreaded choosing a topic, and instead preferred that the instructor provide one for them. This research shows significant potential for writing to learn within the engineering disciplines, as well as insight for assignment design.

 

A final component of this project was to find ways to share evidence-based information about writing students with educators in a way that influenced their educational designs. We provided and tested a case-studies approach, using student stories from interviews as a narrative means to illustrate student motivations, to spur creative insights and evidence-based teaching ideas. Our evaluations of this approach were positive; participating instructors exhibited a positive response to the narrative format, increased evidence of empathy in their responses, and increased creativity in their teaching ideas. It additionally seemed meaningful to instructors to understand that the interviews were drawn from local students?as one remarked, ?I could have passed [the student] on the quad every day.? This dissemination technique suggests a promising role for narrative as a tool to empower educators to enact novel student-centered innovations in their teaching designs.
